climbs.name: The Uneventful
climbs.fa: Harry Daley, Yvon Chouinard, C. Butler, and Dan Doody, October 1959

content.description: This is the longest route at Tahquitz, starting at the lowest point and finishing on the summit.  There is quite a lot of nice climbing along the way.  Follow the left of the two shallow ridges that make up the base of the North Buttress, going up crack systems that gradually get more difficult (to about 5.4) as they change into a left-facing corner system.  After four or five pitches from the ground, this leads to a series of broken ledges with two large trees.  The upper tree has a J shape near the bottom, and marks the upper part of the route (you can belay from a large seat formed by the bottom of the J).  The next pitch is nearly vertical, and the crux of the climb.  It follows a corner -  a crack in the back ranges from one to six inches in width.  After two small overhangs, you go around a corner to the right and onto easier ground.  A few easy pitches lead to the top of the rock.
Face climb up to and then jam a straight in thin crack. It is fun, short and obscure.
content.protection: There was a fixed pin we left on the FA just before the start of the thin crack. I don't know if it is still there. Use thin pro to 2" in the thin crack.
content.location: To the right of the start of Hubris and left of The Uneventful.

content.description: 4 pitch variation on North Buttress. Mostly right facing corner.  Named for the tenuously located bread box sized block that is (was?) located on pitch 2 or 3.
content.location: See modified '85 Vogel guide pic.  Between North Buttress (No. 22 in pic) and The Error (No. 23 in pic)

climbs.name: North Buttress
climbs.fa: R. Smith and Don Wilson, August 1952

content.description: The North Buttress of Tahquitz Rock is split at the bottom, with two ridges.  The North Buttress route starts on the right side of the right ridge.   Four or five pitches (4th class and 5.0) up crack systems on low angle rock lead to a series of broken ledges with two large trees.  The upper tree has a prominent J  shape near the bottom.  From the lower tree, go up a short distance, and then traverse left (crux) across an open face  exposed and not obvious.  The traverse takes you to a crack system  climb up this for two more pitches (5.3) to the top.

Between The original start of Lip up Fatty and the Finger crack variation start, Lies a hidden seam/flake that climbs excellent features to the small triangle shaped roof. Plug in some thin Gear under the roof and fire out left or right (better), to meet back up with The Fatty just under the Angel Wings.

Starts on the bottom left edge of the N. Buttress. look for a "wing" shaped flake with a nice crack running through the middle of it. Work your way up more or less in a direct line up to a nice obvious corner with three roofs. After this pitch work up and right to the right of two obvious long cracks. You know you are in the right crack if you have to pass a crazy flake jutting out of the crack. Pass a roof on the left (really cool and exposed) The pitches are long...bring a 60 m at least. Each pitch is fun with varied challenges and the best part...this route is usually totally unoccupied. (North Buttress bad rap I guess).
content.protection: plenty of small sizes (nuts) and a few medium pieces.

content.description:
Unfortunately this currently has very questionable 1/4 bolts.

Start of a wide layback, run out 5.8 because it would be very difficult to get deep back in the crack to place anything. After a small over hang place some gear high and traverse left to the first bolt. It's up and slightly right from the to a second bolt and then to a small bush. There's supposed to be a two bolt anchor after the bush but I couldn't see it.

For P2 it's, clip a bolt and traverse right, 10b, or go more straight up at 11a. The route finishes into Uneventful.
content.location: Left of Tank Mechanic, right of the Larks. Obvious flake lieback for the start.
